verses.text: Bring near to yourself Aaron your brother, and his sons with him, from among the people of Israel, so that he may serve me as priest—Aaron and his sons: Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
verses.comment: Names and priestly lineage stated directly as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: You shall make holy garments for Aaron your brother, for glory and for beauty.
verses.comment: Follows the emphasis on sacredness of priestly garments.

verses.text: You shall speak to all the skilled craftsmen, whom I have filled with a spirit of wisdom, so that they make Aaron’s garments to consecrate him, that he may serve me as priest.
verses.comment: Rendering 'skillful' as 'skilled craftsmen', matches Hebrew.

verses.text: These are the garments which they shall make: a breastpiece, an ephod, a robe, a tunic of checkered work, a turban, and a sash. They shall make holy garments for Aaron your brother and his sons, so that he may serve me as priest.
verses.comment: Plain listing of garments; 'tunic of checkered work' per Hebrew.

verses.text: They shall use gold, blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and fine linen.
verses.comment: Material list as in original.

verses.text: They shall make the ephod of gold, of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and of fine twisted linen, skillfully worked.
verses.comment: 'Ephod,' transliterated, traditional meaning.

verses.text: It shall have two shoulder pieces attached to its two edges, so that it may be joined together.
verses.comment: Describes the construction of the ephod according to Hebrew structure.

verses.text: And the skillfully woven band on it, which is on the ephod, shall be made with the same work, of one piece with it: of gold, blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and fine twisted linen.
verses.comment: Wording retained from Hebrew idiom—'band' as sash or waistband.

verses.text: You shall take two onyx stones, and engrave on them the names of the sons of Israel,
verses.comment: 'Onyx stones' as literal stone name.

verses.text: six of their names on the one stone, and the remaining six names on the other stone, in the order of their birth.
verses.comment: As per birth order in Genesis.

verses.text: As a jeweler engraves signets, so shall you engrave the two stones with the names of the sons of Israel. You shall enclose them in settings of gold filigree.
verses.comment: ‘Gold filigree’ translates the Hebrew word for braided or plaited gold.

verses.text: Set the two stones on the shoulder pieces of the ephod as stones of remembrance for the sons of Israel. Aaron shall bear their names before the LORD on his two shoulders for remembrance.
verses.comment: 'Remembrance' captures the memorial aspect.

verses.text: You shall make settings of gold filigree,
verses.comment: Literal translation of 'gold filigree.'

verses.text: and two chains of pure gold, twisted like cords; and you shall attach the corded chains to the settings.
verses.comment: Phrase 'twisted like cords' renders Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: You shall make a breastpiece of judgment, in skilled work. Like the work of the ephod, you shall make it—of gold, blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, and fine twisted linen, you shall make it.
verses.comment: 'Breastpiece of judgment' as in Hebrew, refers to decision-making.

verses.text: It shall be square and doubled; a span its length and a span its width.
verses.comment: 'Span' is an ancient measurement (about 9 inches/23 cm).

verses.text: You shall set in it four rows of stones: a row of sardius, topaz, and carbuncle shall be the first row;
verses.comment: Stone names as commonly translated; some uncertainty remains.

verses.text: and the second row an emerald, a sapphire, and a diamond;
verses.comment: Stone names per tradition; see also modern gemstone equivalents.

verses.text: and the third row a jacinth, an agate, and an amethyst;
verses.comment: Jacinth and agate: Hebrew terms uncertain.

verses.text: and the fourth row a beryl, an onyx, and a jasper. They shall be set in gold filigree.
verses.comment: Stone names retained; gold filigree as in v11.

verses.text: The stones shall be according to the names of the sons of Israel, twelve, according to their names. They shall be engraved like signets, each with its name, for the twelve tribes.
verses.comment: Direct reference to the tribes.

verses.text: You shall make for the breastpiece twisted chains like cords, of pure gold.
verses.comment: See v14 for similar description.

verses.text: You shall make for the breastpiece two rings of gold, and put the two rings on the two edges of the breastpiece.
verses.comment: Literal rendering, following the assembly.

verses.text: You shall put the two cords of gold in the two rings at the edges of the breastpiece.
verses.comment: Construction instructions closely followed.

verses.text: The two ends of the two cords you shall attach to the two settings of gold, and so attach them to the shoulder pieces of the ephod in the front.
verses.comment: Assembly language literal to the original.

verses.text: You shall make two rings of gold and put them at the two ends of the breastpiece, on its inside edge next to the ephod.
verses.comment: Placement specifics kept as in Hebrew.

verses.text: You shall make two rings of gold, and attach them to the two shoulder pieces of the ephod, at its lower front, close to the seam above the skillfully woven band of the ephod.
verses.comment: Uses precise placement language.

verses.text: The breastpiece shall be bound by its rings to the rings of the ephod with a blue cord, so that it is above the skillfully woven band of the ephod, so that the breastpiece will not come loose from the ephod.
verses.comment: 'Not come loose' translates Hebrew for 'not be separated.'

verses.text: So Aaron shall bear the names of the sons of Israel in the breastpiece of judgment on his heart, when he goes into the Holy Place, to bring them to regular remembrance before the LORD.
verses.comment: 'On his heart' as a literal idiom, per Hebrew.

verses.text: You shall put in the breastpiece of judgment the Urim and the Thummim, and they shall be on Aaron's heart when he goes in before the LORD. Thus Aaron shall bear the judgment of the people of Israel on his heart before the LORD continually.
verses.comment: Urim and Thummim left untranslated as Hebrew terms; meaning mysterious.

verses.text: You shall make the robe of the ephod all of blue.
verses.comment: 'Blue' is a specific shade (Heb. 'tekeleth').

verses.text: It shall have an opening for the head in the middle of it, with a woven band around the opening, like a collar, so that it may not tear.
verses.comment: Collar's function to prevent tearing.

verses.text: On its hem you shall make pomegranates of blue, purple, and scarlet yarn, around its hem, with bells of gold between them all around,
verses.comment: 'Pomegranates' as decorative yarn work.

verses.text: a golden bell and a pomegranate, a golden bell and a pomegranate, all around the hem of the robe.
verses.comment: Alternating pattern as per the Hebrew.

verses.text: It shall be on Aaron when he serves, and its sound shall be heard when he goes into the Holy Place before the LORD and when he comes out, so that he does not die.
verses.comment: 'So that he does not die'—sacred caution for priestly duty.

verses.text: You shall make a plate of pure gold and engrave on it, like the engraving of a signet: 'HOLY TO THE LORD.'
verses.comment: Phrase matches Hebrew: 'Kodesh l’YHWH.'

verses.text: You shall fasten it on the turban with a blue cord; it shall be on the front of the turban.
verses.comment: Literal placement for the gold plate.

verses.text: It shall be on Aaron’s forehead, and Aaron shall bear any guilt from the holy things which the people of Israel consecrate as their holy offerings; it shall be always on his forehead, that they may be accepted before the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Bear any guilt'—Hebrew has sense of carrying responsibility.

verses.text: You shall weave the tunic of fine linen, and make a turban of fine linen, and you shall make a sash, the work of an embroiderer.
verses.comment: Follows closely instructions for priestly attire.

verses.text: For Aaron’s sons you shall make tunics and sashes and caps; you shall make them for glory and for beauty.
verses.comment: 'Caps' (Heb. migba'ot); not turbans (which only Aaron wears).

verses.text: You shall put them on Aaron your brother, and on his sons with him, and shall anoint them, and ordain them, and consecrate them, that they may serve me as priests.
verses.comment: 'Ordain' (fills their hands); 'consecrate' (set apart).

verses.text: You shall make for them linen undergarments to cover their naked flesh; they shall reach from the hips to the thighs.
verses.comment: 'Undergarments' translates Hebrew 'miknesayim.'

verses.text: They shall be on Aaron and on his sons when they go into the tent of meeting or when they come near to the altar to minister in the Holy Place, so that they do not bear guilt and die. It shall be a statute forever for him and for his offspring after him.
verses.comment: "Statute forever"—in Hebrew, 'le-olam,' a lasting requirement.
